deliberation: Considered whether the prophetic formula is purely literal. The phrase 'the word of YHWH came to me' personifies 'word' as an active agent that can 'come,' and uses 'word' metonymically for God's act of communication. No other figures appear.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיְהִ֥י דְבַר־יְהֹוָ֖ה אֵלַ֥י לֵאמֹֽר
instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me

vehicle: a concrete 'word' that moves toward and arrives at someone
ground: a message originates from one party and reaches another as an intentional act
transmission and arrival of a communication
communication dynamics

instances.explanation: The 'word' of YHWH is personified and treated as if it were an entity that can 'come' to Ezekiel; 'word' also stands metonymically for God's revelation itself.

deliberation: The verse contains the vocative 'ben-adam' (son of man) as a conventional idiom for 'mortal,' and it introduces the central shepherd/flock metaphor where Israel’s leaders are called 'shepherds' and the people 'flock.' These are two distinct figurative expressions.

instances.hebrew_text: בֶּן־אָדָ֕ם
instances.english_text: O mortal (lit. 'son of man')

ground: sharing the nature of humankind, dependent and finite in contrast to God
membership in humanity and mortal status
anthropology/theology of human limitation
posture: reminding the prophet of his human status before God
instances.explanation: ‘Ben-adam’ is an idiomatic expression (with synecdochic flavor) for a human being, emphasizing Ezekiel’s mortal, human nature in contrast to the divine speaker.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־רוֹעֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל ... הֲל֣וֹא הַצֹּ֔אן יִרְע֖וּ הָרֹעִֽים
instances.english_text: against the shepherds of Israel ... Is it not the flock that the shepherds ought to tend?

vehicle: shepherds who tend a flock of sheep
ground: shepherds and leaders both have responsibility to feed, protect, and guide those dependent on them
care, oversight, and accountability for the vulnerable
ethics of authority and governance
posture: indignant accusation of failed, self-serving leadership
instances.explanation: Calling Israel’s leaders 'shepherds' and the people 'flock' is a sustained metaphor that frames leadership as pastoral care which should be directed toward the people rather than toward self-indulgence.

deliberation: The verse elaborates the shepherd metaphor: eating fat, wearing wool, slaughtering fatlings versus tending the flock. These are concrete shepherding actions used figuratively for leaders exploiting their people, but they form one coherent metaphorical picture.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶת־הַחֵ֤לֶב תֹּאכֵ֙לוּ֙ וְאֶת־הַצֶּ֣מֶר תִּלְבָּ֔שׁוּ הַבְּרִיאָ֖ה תִּזְבָּ֑חוּ הַצֹּ֖אן לֹ֥א תִרְעֽוּ
instances.english_text: You partake of the fat, you clothe yourselves with the wool, and you slaughter the fatlings; but you do not tend the flock.

ground: in both cases those in power take resources and life from those entrusted to them instead of providing care
self-indulgent consumption of dependents rather than protection of them
injustice and abuse of entrusted authority
posture: strong moral condemnation of parasitic leadership
instances.explanation: The shepherds’ actions are metaphorical for leaders who live off the people (taking their resources and lives) while failing to provide proper governance and care.

deliberation: The entire verse continues the pastoral imagery of injured, sick, strayed, and lost sheep and contrasts it with harsh driving. This is figurative language for various categories of vulnerable or wayward people and abusive leadership.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶת־הַנַּחְלוֹת֩ לֹ֨א חִזַּקְתֶּ֜ם וְאֶת־הַחוֹלָ֣ה לֹֽא־רִפֵּאתֶ֗ם וְלַנִּשְׁבֶּ֙רֶת֙ לֹ֣א חֲבַשְׁתֶּ֔ם וְאֶת־הַנִּדַּ֙חַת֙ לֹ֣א הֲשֵׁבֹתֶ֔ם וְאֶת־הָאֹבֶ֖דֶת לֹ֣א בִקַּשְׁתֶּ֑ם וּבְחׇזְקָ֛ה רְדִיתֶ֥ם אֹתָ֖ם וּבְפָֽרֶךְ
instances.english_text: You have not sustained the weak, healed the sick, or bandaged the injured; you have not brought back the strayed, or looked for the lost; but you have driven them with harsh rigor.
target: different classes of vulnerable, suffering, or wayward Israelites and the leaders’ treatment of them
socially and spiritually needy people under authority
vehicle: weak, sick, injured, strayed, and lost sheep driven harshly by a shepherd
sheep in various states of need under a negligent shepherd
ground: both sheep and people in these categories depend on attentive care and search; harsh driving wounds them further
need for restorative care versus oppressive treatment of the vulnerable
ethics of compassion and responsibility
posture: indicting leaders for cruelty and negligence toward the weak
instances.explanation: The catalog of weak, sick, injured, strayed, and lost sheep is a pastoral metaphor for vulnerable or erring members of the community whom the leaders should have supported and restored instead of oppressing.

deliberation: The verse describes sheep scattered without a shepherd, becoming food for every wild beast. Within the ongoing pastoral metaphor, this pictures Israel as unprotected and exploited by hostile powers. I treat the scattering and predation as one integrated metaphorical scene.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתְּפוּצֶ֖ינָה מִבְּלִ֣י רֹעֶ֑ה וַתִּהְיֶ֧ינָה לְאׇכְלָ֛ה לְכׇל־חַיַּ֥ת הַשָּׂדֶ֖ה
instances.english_text: and they have been scattered for want of anyone to tend them; scattered, they have become prey for every wild beast.
target: Israel’s people exposed to danger and exploitation by surrounding powers because of failed leadership
vehicle: sheep scattered without a shepherd and eaten by every wild animal
ground: both unguarded sheep and ungoverned people become easy targets for predators/oppressors
lack of protective oversight leads to scattering and destruction
consequences of absent leadership
posture: lamenting the consequences and implicitly condemning those responsible
instances.explanation: Israel is depicted as a scattered flock devoured by 'every wild beast'—a hyperbolic pastoral metaphor for the many hostile forces that prey on an unprotected people.

deliberation: Continues the sheep imagery: 'My sheep' stray on all mountains and high hills and are scattered over 'all the face of the earth.' This combines the flock metaphor with a meristic, hyperbolic description of total dispersion.

instances.hebrew_text: יִשְׁגּ֤וּ צֹאנִי֙ בְּכׇל־הֶ֣הָרִ֔ים וְעַ֖ל כׇּל־גִּבְעָ֣ה רָמָ֑ה וְעַ֨ל כׇּל־פְּנֵ֤י הָאָ֙רֶץ֙ נָפֹ֣צוּ צֹאנִ֔י
instances.english_text: My sheep stray through all the mountains and over every lofty hill; My flock is scattered all over the face of the earth
target: Israelites dispersed geographically and spiritually with no one seeking them
vehicle: sheep wandering over every mountain and high hill, scattered over all the earth’s surface
roaming flock without boundaries or shepherd
ground: both images involve extensive, uncontrolled wandering and isolation without guidance
total lack of rootedness and care leading to dispersion
effects of abandonment by responsible guardians
posture: sorrowful yet accusatory portrayal of abandonment
instances.explanation: The people’s dispersion is portrayed as sheep straying across 'all the mountains' and 'all the face of the earth,' a hyperbolic merism intensifying the metaphor of total scattering.

deliberation: The verse is an address to 'shepherds'—still metaphorical for leaders—but contains no additional imagery beyond that, and 'hear the word of YHWH' is the standard prophetic formula. I treat the shepherd designation itself as the figurative element here.

instances.hebrew_text: לָכֵ֣ן רֹעִ֔ים שִׁמְע֖וּ אֶת־דְּבַ֥ר יְהֹוָֽה

vehicle: shepherds addressed as responsible for a flock
ground: both shepherds and leaders are accountable caretakers whose actions affect those under them
responsibility and accountability for oversight
authority and care roles
posture: solemn summoning of leaders under their pastoral title for judgment
instances.explanation: Calling the leaders 'shepherds' continues the established metaphor, framing them as pastoral caretakers being called to account.

deliberation: This verse restates the flock metaphor: 'My flock has been a spoil,' 'prey for all the wild beasts,' and 'shepherds tended themselves.' The imagery of spoil and prey, and of shepherds feeding on the flock, forms one extended metaphor of exploitation.

instances.hebrew_text: יַ֣עַן הֱיֽוֹת־צֹאנִ֣י לָבַ֡ז וַתִּהְיֶ֩ינָה֩ צֹאנִ֨י לְאׇכְלָ֜ה לְכׇל־חַיַּ֤ת הַשָּׂדֶה֙ ... וַיִּרְע֤וּ הָרֹעִים֙ אוֹתָ֔ם וְאֶת־צֹאנִ֖י לֹ֥א רָעֽוּ
instances.english_text: Because My flock has been a spoil—My flock has been a prey for all the wild beasts ... for the shepherds tended themselves instead of tending the flock
target: Israel’s people plundered by enemies and exploited by their own leaders
vehicle: a flock of sheep taken as loot and eaten by all wild beasts while their shepherds feed themselves
war plunder and predation imagery in a pastoral frame
ground: both a looted flock and an oppressed populace are treated as objects to consume rather than beings to protect
total exposure to predators due to guardian failure
injustice, plunder, and neglect
posture: outraged divine evaluation of leaders’ self-interest and people’s suffering
instances.explanation: Describing the people as 'spoil' and 'prey for all the wild beasts,' and the leaders as shepherds who feed themselves, intensifies the pastoral metaphor into a picture of total exploitation and plunder.

deliberation: A brief command to the 'shepherds' to hear God’s word. The only figurative element is again the designation 'shepherds' for leaders.

instances.hebrew_text: לָכֵן֙ הָרֹעִ֔ים שִׁמְע֖וּ דְּבַר־יְהֹוָֽה

vehicle: shepherds addressed as if they were tending a flock
ground: leaders and shepherds both stand in responsible relation to those under their care
accountability and oversight
authority structures
posture: formal judicial summons under the pastoral metaphor
instances.explanation: Calling the leaders 'shepherds' keeps the metaphorical frame of pastoral responsibility as God confronts them.

deliberation: The key figurative element is 'I will rescue My flock from their mouths,' depicting leaders as predators devouring sheep. This sharpens the shepherd imagery into predatory animal imagery applied to the leaders.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִצַּלְתִּ֤י צֹאנִי֙ מִפִּיהֶ֔ם וְלֹא־תִֽהְיֶ֥יןָ לָהֶ֖ם לְאׇכְלָֽה
instances.english_text: for I will rescue My flock from their mouths, and it shall not be their prey.
target: God’s people whom He will deliver from oppressive leaders
vehicle: sheep being pulled out of the mouths of animals that are eating them
ground: both prey and oppressed people are in the process of being consumed by those stronger than they are
immediate, life-threatening exploitation requiring divine intervention
rescue from violent oppression
posture: promising decisive rescue and judgment against devouring leaders
instances.explanation: Leaders are implicitly likened to beasts whose mouths are full of sheep; God will snatch His 'flock' from their jaws so they are no longer 'prey.'

deliberation: God says He will 'seek' His flock and 'take thought' for them, continuing the shepherd metaphor with Himself as the true shepherd. No additional figures such as similes or hyperbole appear here.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי־אָ֕נִי וְדָרַשְׁתִּ֥י אֶת־צֹאנִ֖י וּבִקַּרְתִּֽים

intentional, searching care and oversight
faithful guardianship
posture: reassuring promise that God Himself will be the true shepherd
instances.explanation: God portrays Himself as a shepherd who will actively seek out and inspect His flock, a metaphor for His direct, restorative involvement with His scattered people.

deliberation: This verse has an explicit simile comparing God’s action to a shepherd seeking his separated flock. It also mentions a 'day of cloud and gloom,' a stock metaphor for a time of judgment or calamity.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּבַקָּרַת֩ רֹעֶ֨ה עֶדְר֜וֹ בְּיוֹם־הֱיוֹת֤וֹ בְתוֹךְ־צֹאנוֹ֙ נִפְרָשׁ֔וֹת כֵּ֖ן אֲבַקֵּ֣ר אֶת־צֹאנִ֑י

ground: both involve a responsible caretaker proactively seeking dispersed dependents to restore them
intentional search, recognition, and retrieval of the separated
careful oversight and reclaiming
posture: reassuring comparison that underscores God’s thoroughness
instances.explanation: The simile directly likens God’s future seeking of His people to a shepherd’s diligent search for separated sheep, clarifying the mode of His care.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּי֥וֹם עָנָ֖ן וַעֲרָפֶֽל
instances.english_text: on a day of cloud and gloom

period of national disaster and divine judgment
vehicle: a day characterized by dark cloud and thick gloom
ground: both dark storm and severe crisis share obscurity, fear, and threat to wellbeing
oppressive, obscuring conditions that bring distress
experience of darkness and danger
posture: viewing the time of judgment as a dark, ominous atmosphere
instances.explanation: The phrase 'day of cloud and gloom' metaphorically characterizes the historical time of scattering as a dark, threatening day, a common biblical image for judgment.

deliberation: The verse mixes relatively literal restoration (bringing them from peoples and lands to 'their own land') with pastoral imagery of pasturing on mountains and by watercourses. Given the sustained metaphor, pasturing here is figurative for God’s comprehensive care in the land.

instances.hebrew_text: וּרְעִיתִים֙ אֶל־הָרֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל בָּאֲפִיקִ֕ים וּבְכֹ֖ל מוֹשְׁבֵ֥י הָאָֽרֶץ

sheep grazing in varied, good locations
ground: as sheep well pastured in all terrains have sustenance and safety, so a restored nation enjoys provision and security throughout its territory
ample, well-distributed provision and care
landed security and nourishment
posture: promissory and nurturing, in contrast to earlier neglect
instances.explanation: To 'pasture' the people on the mountains and by streams continues the sheep metaphor, portraying the restored community as well-fed and securely settled under God’s shepherding.

deliberation: This verse elaborates good pasture and rich grazing on the 'lofty hills of Israel.' The lying down and feeding language continues the extended shepherd/flock metaphor for safety, rest, and abundance.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּמִרְעֶה־טּוֹב֙ אֶרְעֶ֣ה אֹתָ֔ם ... שָׁ֤ם תִּרְבַּ֙צְנָה֙ בְּנָ֣וֶה טּ֔וֹב וּמִרְעֶ֥ה שָׁמֵ֛ן תִּרְעֶ֖ינָה
instances.english_text: I will feed them in good grazing land ... There they shall lie down in a good pasture and shall feed on rich grazing land.

ground: both depictions involve security, rest, and ample nourishment under trustworthy care
state of unthreatened satisfaction and provision
shalom-like wellbeing
posture: warm promise of abundant care, reversing previous deprivation
instances.explanation: Good and 'fat' pasture with sheep lying down functions as a metaphor for a secure, well-provided life for the restored community under God’s shepherding.

deliberation: God states directly that He will 'graze' His flock and make them lie down, explicitly casting Himself as a shepherd. This is a straightforward continuation of the central metaphor without additional figures.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲנִ֨י אֶרְעֶ֤ה צֹאנִי֙ וַאֲנִ֣י אַרְבִּיצֵ֔ם
instances.english_text: I Myself will graze My flock, and I Myself will let them lie down
target: YHWH’s direct governance and care for His people
vehicle: a shepherd feeding his sheep and causing them to lie down to rest

providing sustenance and secure rest
protective guardianship
posture: emphatic assurance of personal divine involvement in care
instances.explanation: By saying He will 'graze' His flock and make them 'lie down,' God uses the shepherd metaphor to promise direct, tender oversight and rest for His people.

deliberation: The verse contrasts God’s care for the lost, strayed, injured, and weak with His destruction of the 'fat and strong.' All are sheep-images applied to people, continuing the pastoral metaphor with a moral/judicial twist.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶת־הָאֹבֶ֤דֶת אֲבַקֵּשׁ֙ ... וְאֶת־הַחוֹלָ֖ה אֲחַזֵּ֑ק וְאֶת־הַשְּׁמֵנָ֧ה וְאֶת־הַחֲזָקָ֛ה אַשְׁמִ֖יד אֶרְעֶ֥נָּה בְמִשְׁפָּֽט
instances.english_text: I will look for the lost, and I will bring back the strayed; I will bandage the injured, and I will sustain the weak; and the fat and healthy ones I will destroy. I will tend them rightly.
target: various groups within Israel (vulnerable vs. oppressive) and God’s differing treatment of them
socially/spiritually needy versus powerful and abusive individuals
vehicle: lost, strayed, injured, weak, and fat/strong sheep cared for or culled by a shepherd
differential treatment of sheep according to condition
ground: as a good shepherd seeks the weak and culls the dangerously dominant, so God restores the vulnerable and judges the powerful oppressors
compassion and corrective justice in care for a flock
ethics of protection and discipline
posture: balancing tender care with firm judgment within the flock
instances.explanation: Lost, weak, and strong sheep symbolize different human conditions; God’s care and destruction in this pastoral frame portray restorative justice within His people.

deliberation: God announces judgment 'between sheep and sheep, between rams and bucks.' This figuratively describes judgment among different groups/individuals within Israel. It is one coherent metaphorical image.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִ֤י שֹׁפֵט֙ בֵּֽין־שֶׂ֣ה לָשֶׂ֔ה לָאֵילִ֖ים וְלָעַתּוּדִֽים

target: different categories or statuses of people within Israel whom God will distinguish and judge
intra-community groups (strong vs. weak, oppressors vs. victims)
vehicle: sheep, rams, and goats within a flock being distinguished by a shepherd-judge
ground: just as a shepherd can distinguish and deal differently with various animals, so God can and will differentiate between kinds of people in His judgment
discernment and differentiated treatment of members of one group
judicial discrimination between cases
posture: asserting God’s impartial, internal justice among His people
instances.explanation: The imagery of judging between sheep, rams, and goats metaphorically portrays God’s discernment and judgment among different people or factions in Israel.

deliberation: The verse uses animal behavior (grazing, trampling pasture, drinking and muddying water) to depict dominant members of the flock spoiling resources for others. This metaphorically indicts stronger members of the community who ruin common goods for the weaker.

instances.hebrew_text: הַמְעַ֣ט מִכֶּ֗ם הַמִּרְעֶ֤ה הַטּוֹב֙ תִּרְע֔וּ וְיֶ֙תֶר֙ מִרְעֵיכֶ֔ם תִּרְמְס֖וּ בְּרַגְלֵיכֶ֑ם וּמִשְׁקַע־מַ֣יִם תִּשְׁתּ֔וּ וְאֵת֙ הַנּ֣וֹתָרִ֔ים בְּרַגְלֵיכֶ֖ם תִּרְפֹּשֽׂוּן
instances.english_text: Is it not enough for you to graze on choice grazing ground, but you must also trample with your feet what is left from your grazing? And is it not enough for you to drink clear water, but you must also muddy with your feet what is left?

vehicle: animals that eat the best pasture and trample the rest, drink clear water and muddy what is left with their feet
ground: both pictures involve taking more than needed and degrading remaining resources so others cannot benefit
selfish consumption and active harming of the common good
injustice and lack of regard for the weak
posture: sharp moral rebuke of the strong for wrecking provision for others
instances.explanation: The description of animals trampling pasture and muddying water functions as a metaphor for community members whose greed and behavior ruin what remains for the rest.

deliberation: This rhetorical question reiterates the image from verse 18, focusing on the flock forced to eat trampled pasture and drink muddied water. It is the same metaphor of the oppressed consuming degraded resources because of the strong.

instances.hebrew_text: וְצֹאנִ֑י מִרְמַ֤ס רַגְלֵיכֶם֙ תִּרְעֶ֔ינָה וּמִרְפַּ֥שׂ רַגְלֵיכֶ֖ם תִּשְׁתֶּֽינָה
instances.english_text: And must My flock graze on what your feet have trampled and drink what your feet have muddied?
target: the disadvantaged members of Israel forced to live on what the powerful have degraded
vehicle: sheep eating trampled pasture and drinking muddied water left by others’ feet

living off what is degraded by the powerful
systemic inequity in resource distribution
posture: expressing outrage at the injustice visited upon 'My flock'
sympathetic toward victims, accusatory toward oppressors
instances.explanation: The image of sheep forced to graze trampled grass and drink muddied water metaphorically portrays the plight of the weak who must subsist on what the powerful have spoiled.

deliberation: God declares He will judge 'between fat sheep and lean sheep.' 'Fat' and 'lean' sheep represent privileged vs. deprived people within the community; this is one metaphorical contrast of internal social stratification.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשָֽׁפַטְתִּי֙ בֵּֽין־שֶׂ֣ה בִרְיָ֔ה וּבֵ֥ין שֶׂ֖ה רָזָֽה
instances.english_text: I am going to decide between the stout animals and the lean.
target: well-off oppressors versus deprived victims within Israel
vehicle: fat (well-nourished) and lean (emaciated) sheep distinguished by a shepherd-judge
contrasting physical conditions in a flock
ground: fat sheep and privileged people both display signs of overabundance, while lean sheep and the poor show deprivation
visible disparity within one group that calls for corrective judgment
inequity and imbalance needing redress
posture: assertive commitment to redress inequalities among His people
instances.explanation: The contrast between 'fat' and 'lean' sheep metaphorically represents disparities between powerful, overfed individuals and the undernourished weak whom God will judge between.

deliberation: The verse describes animals pushing with side and shoulder and butting with horns until others are scattered. Within the flock metaphor this portrays aggressive, domineering behavior by powerful people toward the weak.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּצַ֤ד וּבְכָתֵף֙ תֶּהְדֹּ֔פוּ וּבְקַרְנֵיכֶ֥ם תְּנַגְּח֖וּ כׇּל־הַנַּחְל֑וֹת עַ֣ד אֲשֶׁ֧ר הֲפִיצוֹתֶ֛ם אוֹתָ֖נָה אֶל־הַחֽוּצָה
instances.english_text: Because you pushed with flank and shoulder against the feeble ones and butted them with your horns until you scattered them abroad
target: strong members of the community who bully and drive out the weaker ones
vehicle: robust animals pushing with side and shoulder and goring others with horns, scattering them
ground: both depict the strong using physical force to displace and scatter the feeble
coercive dominance that causes the weak to be driven out
abuse of strength and resulting fragmentation
posture: condemning aggressive oppression within the flock/people
instances.explanation: Pushing with flank and shoulder and butting with horns is a metaphor for the powerful using their advantage to harm and scatter the feeble members of the community.

deliberation: God will 'save My flock' so they are no longer 'spoil' and again will 'judge between sheep and sheep.' These are reiterations of the flock metaphor and internal judgment; I treat them as one combined instance here.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהוֹשַׁעְתִּ֣י לְצֹאנִ֔י וְלֹא־תִהְיֶ֥ינָה ע֖וֹד לָבַ֑ז וְשָׁ֣פַטְתִּ֔י בֵּ֥ין שֶׂ֖ה לָשֶֽׂה
instances.english_text: I will rescue My flock and they shall no longer be a spoil. I will decide between one animal and another.
target: God’s people who will be delivered from exploitation and judged among themselves
oppressed community and its internal factions
vehicle: a flock no longer taken as spoil, among whom a shepherd judges between individual sheep
ground: just as a good shepherd both protects his animals from being taken and adjudicates intra-flock issues, God will protect and judge among His people
protection from external plunder and fair internal regulation
comprehensive oversight
posture: promising both salvation from predators and fair judgment within the community
instances.explanation: Rescuing 'My flock' from being 'spoil' and judging 'between sheep and sheep' continues the metaphor of God as shepherd protecting and justly governing His people.

deliberation: A 'single shepherd'—'My servant David'—will shepherd and tend them. This applies the shepherd metaphor to the future Davidic ruler, and 'David' itself likely functions metonymically for the Davidic line or an ideal descendant.

instances.hebrew_text: וַהֲקִמֹתִ֨י עֲלֵיהֶ֜ם רֹעֶ֤ה אֶחָד֙ ... אֵ֖ת עַבְדִּ֣י דָוִ֑יד ה֚וּא יִרְעֶ֣ה אֹתָ֔ם
instances.english_text: Then I will appoint a single shepherd over them to tend them—My servant David. He shall tend them, he shall be a shepherd to them.
target: the future ideal ruler from David’s line who will lead and care for Israel
vehicle: a single shepherd caring for and feeding a flock
ground: both a shepherd and a just king provide unified, protective, nourishing leadership for those under them
centralized, benevolent authority and care
model governance
posture: positive, hopeful portrayal of future leadership as true shepherding
instances.explanation: The promised 'shepherd' identified as 'My servant David' metaphorically portrays a coming Davidic ruler as a shepherd-king; the name 'David' functions metonymically for his enduring dynasty or ideal descendant.

deliberation: Here God says He will be their God and 'My servant David' will be 'prince among them.' The main potential figure is 'David' as a metonymy for a Davidic ruler, not necessarily the historical David resurrected. There is no explicit pastoral imagery here.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעַבְדִּ֥י דָוִ֖ד נָשִׂ֣יא בְתוֹכָ֑ם
instances.english_text: and My servant David shall be a ruler among them
target: the future ruler from David’s line who will govern Israel
Davidic kingship in its ideal/restored form
vehicle: the personal name 'David' used as the label for that future ruler
ground: the future ruler is defined by continuity with David’s line and qualities, so David’s name can stand for that office
representative use of the founding figure’s name for his lineage
metonymic naming in royal ideology
posture: affirming continuity with the Davidic covenant and idealizing that rule
instances.explanation: The mention of 'My servant David' uses David’s name metonymically for a future Davidic prince who will rule among the people.

deliberation: The 'covenant of peace' is a theological term; the removal of 'vicious beasts' and safety in wilderness and woods can be read literally, but in the chapter’s flow they also extend the earlier metaphor of beasts as threats (nations/hostile forces). I treat the beast-removal and fearless dwelling as one figurative assurance of comprehensive safety.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִשְׁבַּתִּ֥י חַיָּֽה־רָעָ֖ה מִן־הָאָ֑רֶץ וְיָשְׁב֤וּ בַמִּדְבָּר֙ לָבֶ֔טַח וְיָשְׁנ֖וּ בַּיְּעָרִֽים
instances.english_text: I will banish vicious beasts from their land, and they shall live secure in the wasteland, they shall even sleep in the woodland.
target: God’s people freed from external and internal threats, living in comprehensive security
the community’s experience of peace and safety
vehicle: removal of dangerous wild animals and the ability to dwell and sleep safely even in wilderness and forests
ground: just as there is complete safety when all predators are gone and even wild places are secure, so the restored people will enjoy pervasive peace without fear
absence of threat in all environments
total security
posture: strong reassurance of peace extending to all areas of life
instances.explanation: The banishment of 'vicious beasts' and safe sleeping in the wilderness figuratively portray a state of comprehensive peace where hostile forces (earlier likened to beasts) are eliminated.

deliberation: God will make 'them and the environs of My hill' a blessing and send 'rains of blessing.' 'My hill' is a metonymy for Zion / the central sanctuary-city, and rain functions as both literal provision and symbolic blessing. I treat 'my hill' as the clearest figurative element.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתִּ֥י אוֹתָ֛ם וּסְבִיב֥וֹת גִּבְעָתִ֖י בְּרָכָ֑ה
instances.english_text: I will make these and the environs of My hill a blessing
target: Zion/Jerusalem and its surrounding population and territory
central worship center and its environs
vehicle: ‘My hill’ (גִּבְעָתִי) as a physical elevation belonging to God
sacred hill as shorthand for the sanctuary-city
ground: the temple mount or city is located on a hill and functions as God’s special dwelling, so 'My hill' stands for that cultic-political center
place-associated identity and representation
metonymic designation of sacred space
posture: positively portraying the central hill/city as a source and locus of blessing
instances.explanation: ‘My hill’ uses the physical hill as a metonymy for Zion/Jerusalem (God’s dwelling and rule), whose environs God will make a blessing.

deliberation: The first half (trees yielding fruit, land yield) can be literal. The key figurative clause is 'when I break the bars of their yoke and rescue them from the hand of those who enslave them,' a standard metaphor of oppressive bondage as a yoke with bars that can be broken.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּשִׁבְרִי֙ אֶת־מֹט֣וֹת עֻלָּ֔ם וְהִ֨צַּלְתִּ֔ים מִיַּ֖ד הָעֹבְדִ֥ים בָּהֶֽם
instances.english_text: when I break the bars of their yoke and rescue them from those who enslave them
target: Israel’s experience of political and economic oppression and God’s act of liberation
state of subjugation under foreign rule or exploiters
vehicle: a yoke with bars placed on animals, which can be shattered to free them
beasts of burden under a wooden yoke
ground: both a yoke and oppressive rule impose burdensome control; breaking the yoke and rescuing from a master correspond to liberation from domination
heavy, constraining control and its removal
oppression vs. freedom
posture: celebratory promise of emancipation from oppressive powers
instances.explanation: The 'bars of their yoke' metaphorically depict oppressive rule as a physical yoke on laboring animals; God’s 'breaking' of it symbolizes liberation from those who enslave them.

deliberation: They will no longer be 'spoil for the nations,' and 'the beasts of the earth shall not devour them'; they will dwell secure with 'none to make them afraid.' 'Spoil' and 'beasts devouring' extend the earlier images of plunder and predatory nations within the flock/predator metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וְלֹא־יִהְי֨וּ ע֥וֹד בַּז֙ לַגּוֹיִ֔ם וְחַיַּ֥ת הָאָ֖רֶץ לֹ֣א תֹאכְלֵ֑ם
instances.english_text: They shall no longer be a spoil for the nations, and the beasts of the earth shall not devour them
target: Israel’s cessation of being plundered and destroyed by foreign powers and other threats
vehicle: plunder (spoil) taken by victors and wild beasts that eat prey
ground: in war, defeated peoples are treated as spoil, and like prey devoured by beasts; protection from both pictures safety from exploitation and violence
being treated as consumable objects vs. being secure
exposure to vs. freedom from destructive powers
posture: confident assurance of an end to exploitation and predation
instances.explanation: To no longer be 'spoil' and not be 'devoured' by beasts figuratively expresses that the people will cease to be plundered and destroyed by hostile nations and forces.

deliberation: God will raise up for them 'a planting of renown' (מַטָּע לְשֵׁם). This likely symbolizes a community/land that is fruitful and honored. The phrase is metaphorical; famine and disgrace removal are then stated literally or semi-literally.

instances.hebrew_text: וַהֲקִמֹתִ֥י לָהֶ֛ם מַטָּ֖ע לְשֵׁ֑ם
instances.english_text: I shall establish for them a planting of renown
target: a stable, fruitful, and honored state for God’s people (and/or their land)
vehicle: a 'planting' that has a name or renown
well-established, notable plantation or tree stand
ground: as a well-rooted, fruitful planting gains recognition and endures, so the restored people/land will be fruitful, secure, and honored among nations
stability, productivity, and reputation
growth and esteem
posture: positive elevation of the people’s status and wellbeing
instances.explanation: The 'planting of renown' metaphor portrays the community (or its land) as a well-established, fruitful planting whose flourishing will be recognized, countering famine and disgrace.

deliberation: The verse states the covenant formula 'I am YHWH their God with them and they ... are My people' and refers to 'the house of Israel.' The main figurative element is 'house of Israel,' a metonym/synecdoche where 'house' stands for the whole nation descended from Israel/Jacob.

instances.hebrew_text: בֵּ֣ית יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל
instances.english_text: the House of Israel
vehicle: a 'house' belonging to or consisting of Israel
ground: a house can stand for the whole family or dynasty dwelling in it; likewise 'House of Israel' stands for Israel’s descendants collectively
use of a family/household term to denote a whole people
synecdochic and metonymic naming
posture: affirming corporate identity in covenant relationship
instances.explanation: The expression 'House of Israel' uses the image of a household to stand metonymically and synecdochically for the entire nation descended from Israel.

deliberation: This verse explicitly restates the pastoral metaphor: 'you—My flock, the flock of My pasture—are human.' The first part is metaphorical (people as God’s flock and pasture-sheep), while the second part clarifies the literal referent. I treat the flock/pasture image as one major metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאַתֵּ֥ן צֹאנִ֛י צֹ֥אן מַרְעִיתִ֖י אָדָ֣ם אַתֶּ֑ם
instances.english_text: For you—My flock, the flock that I tend—are human
target: God’s human people in covenant with Him
covenant people as humans under divine care
vehicle: a flock of sheep belonging to and pastured by a shepherd
sheep of a pasture under a shepherd’s care
pastoral image of ownership and provision
ground: both sheep and God’s people depend on a caretaker for provision, protection, and guidance
belonging to a caretaker and living off his pasture
dependence, ownership, and sustained care
posture: clarifying the metaphor while reinforcing intimacy and responsibility
interpretive closure to the shepherd-flock imagery
instances.explanation: By calling them 'My flock, the flock of My pasture,' God reaffirms the shepherd metaphor—He owns, feeds, and cares for them like a shepherd—then explicitly states that these 'sheep' are actually human.
